no billets dropt by your officious maid, on pretence they are meant for some carotty-pated country cousin!

sp.speaker: Viola.
sp.p: Dear Sir!

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: No pencil'd assignations on the back of your fan; or cards in lemon juice—to be call'd on detection secret orders to your perfumer, for pearl powder, and bloom of Circassia.

sp.speaker: Seraph.
sp.p: How can you put such things in the girl's head, deary?

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: (aside) That her fingers may put them in practice, to be sure; but you are not up to me there, deary! (aside.)

sp.speaker: Viola.
sp.p: But a few minutes since, you were fearful, Sir, that he was not received with sufficient favour.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: That was—that—well, no matter. That was, perhaps, to try how far things had gone.

sp.speaker: Seraph.
sp.p: Oh I beg your pardon! the curtain rises, and we see the sun! Now I understand your policy—how admirable! You middle-aged gentlemen are so deep, that 'tis difficult to sift ye.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Ay, and when we are sifted—

sp.speaker: Seraph.
sp.p: You are found to be chaff. Poor dear Don Octavio! Send him a garland of willows, Viola.

sp.speaker: Viola.
sp.p: Rather of myrtles—he's too handsome for willows.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Handsome is he, that handsome does— remember that.

sp.speaker: Viola.
sp.p: Why Sir, he does handsomely. He has travell'd handsomely, has a handsome estate, has brought home a handsome character, and now wishes for a handsome wife.

sp.speaker: Alex,
sp.p: Ay, but he must go further a field to catch her though. He'll find neither wives nor widgeons in my orchard.

sp.speaker: Seraph.
sp.p: No, our widgeons are all within doors.

sp.speaker: Viola.
sp.p: Unfortunate that I am! just made up my mind to dismiss Sebastian, nay absolutely to dislike him, and now—

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: And now! why now you must make up your mind t'other way. Perhaps in my present humour, of the two fools, I like Sebastian best.

sp.speaker: Viola.
sp.p: But that humour must change, for I can never think of those two young men as you do, my dear father.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Thoughts are free, daughter! Gad I could hug her. (aside.)

sp.speaker: Seraph.
sp.p: You see your father generously leaves your thoughts unshackled, my dear; he only desires to controul your actions—pray oblige him, and take Sebastian.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: (aside) Zounds! she knows nothing of our plot, and gives that advice seriously.

sp.speaker: Seraph.
sp.p: He is a most accomplish'd young man.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Wise!

sp.speaker: Seraph.
sp.p: Engaging in his manners, and resistless in his form.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: My dear, I say. (spitefully.)

sp.speaker: Seraph.
sp.p: His eyes are expressive, and his tongue is eloquent.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: The devil's in your tongue! (aside.) You don't know what you are talking of.

sp.speaker: Seraph.
sp.p: I do indeed—perfectly. In short, Viola, he is so amiable, so captivating, and loves you with such unbounded fondness, that if you marry any other, your misery ought to equal your ingratitude.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Gad she speaks with an air of too much conviction—this must be managed more nicely. To your chamber, hussey, and try to forget Octavio.

sp.speaker: Seraph.
sp.p: And remember your Sebastian. Let him be present to you waking, and sleeping; let him—

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Zounds let him alone! (driving her off on the other side) you may be doing mischief all this while. I dare not let her into my plot, lest her perverseness, or her folly should mar it. And yet, I think—no hang it I won't—I won't. The only plot that ever had a woman in it came to nothing. I'll conduct this solely by my own sagacity, and have a hearty laugh at the poor fools, when all is over.

div2.head: SCENE, An elegant Apartment at Don Gasper's, illuminated.
div2.stage: Rachel enters first; followed by Gasper, Antonia, Clara, and a number of Ladies.

sp.speaker: Rach.
sp.p: (looking back) Bless us! the approach of the ceremony has made my master half out of his senses. The poor bride too seems half out of her's—but not with joy—if I may guess.

sp.speaker: Don Gasp.
sp.l: Tired of dance, of song, and play,
sp.p: Yes, yes, now for the ceremony! Come my pretty Pet, the Priest is waiting in the next room to make thee the happiest girl in Portugal. In ten minutes thou wilt be the wife of Don. Gasper de Frontado! (strutting.)

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: (Aside) Oh heaven! where is Henry? Rachel, my soul sinks within me.

sp.speaker: Rach.
sp.p: Truly, mine is not very high.

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: Heyday! what's all this about? What! she must be coax'd now I warrant—they all love coaxing. Come now, my pretty Tony, my nown little Tony. (Taking her under his arm.)

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: (breaking from him) Henry! Henry! Where art thou? Oh, he mocks me!

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: Come, let us to the priest, and tie the knot, which even Alexander who cut the gordion will never be able to destroy.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: (without.) Where is he—the bridegroom! the happy bridegroom!

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Oh my heart—he is come!

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: Here he is—here is the happy bridegroom. (Henry enters) Come, you are just in time to witness the ceremony.—The priest waits to join us in his rosy bands. Look at her! h-u-m! Oh, you sweet little—There are smiles and blushes for ye! Look at her!

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: They are like those of Aurora, when she slies before the jolly god of day!

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: And I the jolly god of day pursue her.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: But charming Antonia, the blissful fate which awaits you must be postponed a few hours. Oh, Sir, I am sent—

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: Sent—about what! from whom?—who has sent you to postpone Antonia's bliss?

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: It is happy I have a token to convince you. Here, Sir, — do you know this great scal ring? the impression is—stay, can you see it? (taking a candle) the impression is a satyr; look at his horns.

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p:
The devil's in such luck! A man on the wrong side of fifty or so, can't marry but at every turn he has horns in his teeth. If he's invited to a tavern, the dinner is sure to be at the horns: They'll wake me with horns to-morrow morning
—nay, I am even kept from the ceremony tonight, to be regaled with the sight of horns.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: (to Clara.) What can be the purport of the ring? I can hardly breathe thro' terror!

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: Do you know them, Sir?

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: Know them! Yes—they are Don Alexis's horns, not mine—it is his ring; —but what have I to do with it, any more than with the ring of Saturn, or the belt of Jupiter? If you are for rings, you shall see one presently (taking Antonia's hand) on this waxen finger, that—

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: You will not hear me, Sir. This is a token from Don Alexis—observe me, Sir, a token; by which you are required, as a counsellor of the realm, to meet Don Alexis immediately at his own house, on affairs of imminent importance.

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: Meet Don Alexis! What is he mad? or are you mad? or does he think me mad? Go, prithee—I'll meet him to-morrow. (seizing Antonia's hand) My service to his night cap! (going.)

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: To-morrow! Why, all our throats may be cut by to-morrow.

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: Hey! throats cut!

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: Why Sir, there's a plot—a plot.

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: A plot!

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: (to Ant.) Now I have his design. My dear Don Gasper, at a juncture so important, every selfish consideration must be annihilated. Should our discontented citizens take arms—

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: Nay, for aught I know they are in arms already.

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: Arms! well what can I do? Fight dog fight bear—I'll be married. (going.)

sp.speaker: Rachel.
sp.p: (dropping on her knee) Oh dear Sir, there'll be nothing but rapes and murder! Oh take pity on us poor virgins, Sir, and go.

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: Don't be a fool! (striving to get free.)

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: Consider, Sir, the good of the nation.

sp.speaker: Rach.
sp.p: Ay, Sir, the good of the nation;—what wouldn't a body do for the good of the nation?

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: Good of the nation!—'twould be a shame! Go—go Julio, and vote for me; I'll make you my proxy.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: Your proxy there, Sir! No, no, excuse me. But hasten;—whilst you dally, all Lisbon may be fired.

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: If there's such danger, I am safest here— an't I, duck? (to Ant.)

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Oh Sir, if you can resist the calls of honour, do not resist me. To marry in the midst of such horrible apprehensions, is impossible—and my fears are so great, they will destroy me. Sweet Don Gasper, go!

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: Nay then—come, my dear Nephew, let us go together; not a step will I move without you.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: (aside) Oh miserable, to be thus circumvented. Had I not better stay here to guard the—

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: Stay here!—Oh you are a dutiful Nephew. No, Sir, you shall guard me, if I stir—but I won't stir by all—

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Fye, Don Julio! surely you will not desert your uncle. Leave him in the street, and return instantly! (apart) Adieu, sweet bridegroom, (helping to get him out) speed quickly back, (looking after them) but find Antonia gone! Dear liberty, I hail thee! Oh Rachel, now I claim thy promise; —assist my flight, and make thy terms and fortune. Follow—follow me! Exit.

sp.speaker: Rachel.
sp.p: I will—but let me consider first what I have engaged to do, to make my fortune. Why I am to assist a pretty girl to run away from an old husband to a young one; from age, gout, and petulance, to youth, health, and glowing love. Ay, that I will, or may I never arrive at higher honour than to attend misses in their bibs, and antient maidens in their spectacles!

div2.stage: A Table with Candles and Chairs.
He enters, followed by a Servant.

sp.speaker: Alexis.
sp.p: HEY dey! why what's the meaning of all this? The family are all up, though it is past twelve o'clock, and my wife's apartments in a blaze—illuminated! as though it was some grand anniversary. What's the meaning of all this, I say?

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Donna Seraphina has ladies with her, Sir—they have been playing.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Playing! go, get along and let me know when they break up. (Exit Servant.) There's no having any rest in this world.—No, or at least not for the husbands of this world.—This custom of letting one's wives receive female company, is like shutting your gates upon the enemy, and then helping them over the wall. Not a woman but has her head full of projects, and her pockets of billets-doux. Well, if at last Don Octavio should really marry my daughter, I shall then hope—

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Don Gasper de Frontado is without, Sir.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Don Gasper—Don Gasper! it can't be.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: He is indeed, Sir, attended by most of his servants, with drawn swords and torches.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Swords and torches—why he's mad! the near approach of matrimony has turn'd his brain. Well, no great wonder. It is Gasper sure enough! (looking through the wing) What a figure!—

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: (Speaking as he enters) Bless me, why all is quiet—all is quiet, my dear nephew! ah (looking back) what's he gone? Not a voice in the street, but two old women quarrelling about a string of sausages.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: (Aside.) Ay it is so—he's certainly crazy. I am very sorry Don Gasper (gravely taking off his hat) that any thing should have happen'd to call you from your house, at this time.

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: My house—that's nothing! From my bride—from my little Tony—from the very altar, my friend. But that is nothing—the good of the nation must be minded. Come let us sit and to business.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: As soon as you please. Zounds, what a time for him to think on the good of the nation! (aside.)

div2.stage: (They both draw chairs, and sit looking at one another, waiting for each to begin.)

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: Be brief—my good friend, be brief!

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Brief—why we hav'nt begun yet.

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: Then why the devil don't we? How long am I to wait, before the mighty matter is brought upon the carpet? Do you consider that I am on the point of being married, Sir?

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Pray, Sir, what would you be at?

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: I be at—I want to know what you would be at.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha,—why this is the strangest thing! to see an old fellow, high in the state, the night he should be married, forsake his bride, and come with a train arm'd cap-à-piè, to disturb another old fellow, and ask him what he would be at! What's your business once more?

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: My business, with whom?

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: With me, Sir—with me! What the devil do you do here?

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: That's what I want to know, Sir, and you'd best be quick in the relation! You seem to think time of no more value to me than straw.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: (rising) Ay, straw—there it is! I thought he was mad; they never think of any thing but straw. I am sorry you are thus disturbed, Don Gasper.

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: (Pursuing him) The disturbance is nothing, if you would but come to the point— What is the plot—Where are the conspirators, and what do they aim at?

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Poor soul—poor soul! My dear friend you really shock me very much—tho' I knew your marriage was a mad action, I did not think it would have taken effect so soon.

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: Oons! this is beyond all bearing! (making a motion as tho' to his sword, and seems disappointed) no sword—meet me to-morrow, Sir— meet me to-morrow!

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: With all my heart. By that time you'll be in a strait waistcoat, and I shall be safe. (Aside.)

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: I am cooler. Such old men as we are can afford to waste no blood—but there's your ring, Sir; and let that be the last token of good, or ill will, you ever send me. (Flinging the ring from him.)

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: My ring! (taking it from the floor) why, how came you—who gave you this ring? who gave it you?

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: Why did not,—did not—oh, my mind misgives me!

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: You had it from your nephew—eh?

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: Ye—y-e-s. (Trembling.)

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha,—oh, a young rogue—oh, a plotting young villain! ha, ha, ha—

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: What then I have—oh, shame to my years—I have been made a jest of.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: A jest—Heaven grant you may be made nothing worse of! Hurry home my dear friend; you know what I said to-day about your bride's odd fancies. Hurry home, and be thankful if it is a jest!

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: What do you imagine—do you conceive—oh, my dear, dear friend! But hold, you are in the plot—the ring is your's—you are in the plot! (Ragefully.)

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Believe me Don Gasper—

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: Oh, what a beetle, what a bat, I have been! but I'll repay your jest with interest. In the first place—and that's only for a beginning mind me, only for a beginning—my Octavio shall never marry your daughter. How d'ye like that jest? Oh what a blind—blind—oh! (Going off stamping.)

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p:
(going after him) My dear Don Gasper, my friend, my worthy friend, I entreat—Zounds! he's gone! If it had not been for his choak-pear about Octavio, how I could laugh. Why, what the plague did that impertinent Don Julio take such a liberty with my ring for? how dared he haul me head and ears into his scheme, to laugh at his worthy uncle? But zooks it is a good laugh
after all — ha, ha, ha—but if Gasper now, thro' spite, should prevent Octavio's marriage! What's to be done? hang me if I go to bed to night— I'll find out Octavio wherever he is, make him steal my daughter, conclude the marriage, and then I'll laugh with Julio, 'till my old sides crack. Exit.

head.stage: SCENE changes to the Street, before Don Gasper's.

div2.stage: He knocks gently at the door.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: I dare not be louder; but sure the ear of love can catch the gentlest sound!

sp.speaker: Rach.
sp.p: (from the balcony) Oh, are you come, Sir—I'll call my lady down.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: Oh haste! the minutes fly; I have secur'd a safe retreat—leave all behind, and bring Antonia only to my arms. (A noise of people advancing) Hah! what noise is that? and lights too! they come this way—surely 'tis Don Gasper's voice—I am breathless with my fears.

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: (without) Put out your lights—extinguish your torches, and be silent.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: Ay, 'tis he—shall I plunge this sword into his bosom, or my own? oh, either way I'm lost! (Don Gasper enters, and knocks loudly.)

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: Yes, yes, I'll be a match for his great grandsires, ring, trust me! (Knocks again.)

sp.speaker: Rachel.
sp.p: (from the balcony) We are just ready, Sir—have a moment's patience.

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p:
Just ready for what? Oh I am arrived in the very nick of some cursed scheme! Keep your swords drawn. (to his servants) Come, I'll not give
way to suspicions—she shall have fair play—appearances may deceive.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: Hah! by Heaven, Antonia — we are ruin'd!

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Where are you, my best wishes? lord of my vows, and charmer of my soul, where are you?

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: Oh heavens! (half drawing his sword.)

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: Well, well, that may be all meant for me.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Give me your hand, my love, my life, and guide me to your bosom—the home for which I pant!

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: Hum—that is rather too much, too! I'm afraid that's too sweet a morsel to be meant for my chops.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: (groping about) Oh, are you here indeed? you frighten'd me with your silence. Here take these jewels, and let us haste away.

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: H-a-h, are you thereabouts, madam? (between his teeth) then I'm cozen'd.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: (aside) To attempt to force her off would be in vain.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Will you not speak? do you repent already? before possession are you cold, and false?

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: Before —ah, ah! —well that's great comfort. Whatever is design'd, I am beforehand with the mischief, however.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Am I not to be your wife?—this very day did we not invoke Heaven to bless our vows?

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: Now then 'tis clearly me, and I'll be mute no longer.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Oh Henry! Henry! (mournfully.)

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: (starting) Who dost thou take me for— Henry? Oh thou perfidious wretch!

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Don Gasper—what will become of me? Why—why are you so angry, Sir, at my naming one who in the cold grave cannot rival you? I was only going to say, that Henry would not have been so unkindly silent.

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: Was that all indeed, my little Tony? but 'twas wrong to think upon a young man. Never let your thoughts run upon a young man, whether in a grave, or a garret.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Never, Sir, be assured. Neither in one place, or the other, will my thoughts ever seek a lover. But why did you not speak?

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: Faith, you prattled love so prettily, I could have heard your little tongue run for ever. But how came you out so late, and with these jewels, and parcels?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Sir!—I was—why Sir—

sp.speaker: Rachel.
sp.p: Alas, Sir, we thought the city was in arms, and pack'd up our things to secure 'em. Lord, Sir, we were so scared! about plots, and robberies, and—

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, terrified to death.

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: Oh it's all quell'd now—'tis all over, my pretty chuck. As soon as I appear'd amongst 'em, and threaten'd 'em, and harangued 'em on their duty, they were as silent as the soft tread of a thief on a dark stair-case. I am resolv'd she shan't know what a gull I was. (aside) Come now let's in, and join our tender hearts in one.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Pardon me, Sir. Day is on the point of breaking—dear welcome day! and I am resolv'd to pass it unbound by any vows, but those of love.

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: How!

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: In this one point, Sir, I must govern, or here I vow most solemnly, never to be yours.

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: Oh its a rash vow—a most unjustifiable vow!

sp.speaker: Rach.
sp.p: Not so rash a vow as that you want her to make.

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: What's that, minx?

sp.speaker: Rach.
sp.p: Why Sir, with submission, I say its most rash and unjustifiable, for eighteen to rise out of bed, and go to church, to vow to love sixty-five— and I'll maintain it.

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: But the vow was made, hussey, and all vows must be kept—religiously kept! and therefore, though it goes against me, even this last shall be kept. So come in, my little Tony, and learn of your nown Hubby, never to break a vow.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: That secures me! Her delicacy is safe from insult, and when I see her next, it shall be with powers to suppress his audacious, fancied rights, and close the necessity for these degrading acts for ever. Exit.

head.stage: SCENE changes to Don Alexis's Garden.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Gad I am glad I found ye—'twas devilish lucky! Viola is certainly somewhere in the garden—both my wife and Carlota assured me that she was.

sp.speaker: Octav.
sp.p: And the ladder of ropes is suspended from the place you pointed out.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Exactly there—I help'd to fix it myself— 'tis very secure.

sp.speaker: Octav.
sp.p: The dear little madcap must have her way; but 'tis strange she prefers scaling a wall at midnight, to walking quietly thro' the gate in the sunshine. Hist!—I hear the tread of gentle feet.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Then I'm off. If she should find us together, the perverse baggage would suspect our intelligence, and that would spoil all—so I'm off! (lowering his voice.) Exit.

sp.speaker: Octav.
sp.p: In a few hours, expect us at your feet asking pardon and blessing. (A pause.) Charming Viola, appear! I hear you not; yet by the soft influence about me, I am sure you are near. What delightful faculty is this, which allows us to be conscious of the presence of the object we adore, without the vulgar intervention of the senses?— It must be the privilege of purest love!

sp.speaker: Seraph.
sp.p: (entering.) The privilege of fancy— all mere fancy; tho' you would exalt it into a faculty!

sp.speaker: Octav.
sp.p: Hah, my charmer! (catching her in his arms) faculties, and fancies, are now equally nothing;—all lost in transport, at finding thee in my arms.

sp.speaker: Seraph.
sp.p: I protest I begin to believe you very dangerous. I insist on your quitting me this instant. (breaking from him) Heavens what a situation! in the arms of a man—alone—in a garden, at two o'clock in the morning? (Aside.)

sp.speaker: Octav.
sp.p: What dost think of, sweet angel?

sp.speaker: Seraph.
sp.p: That the sooner we are out of this place the better.

sp.speaker: Octav.
sp.p: (Aside.) Suppose I secure her mine! I almost fear some new caprice—and if I mistake not, her little heart flutters at this moment, in unison with my own. Dear bewitching woman, let me once more taste—

sp.speaker: Seraph.
sp.p: Hold, Sir! or by all that's good— (breaking from him) I never knew till now what resistance meant. (Aside.)

sp.speaker: Octav.
sp.p: By heavens I will not lose this charming moment!

sp.speaker: Seraph.
sp.p: Then you lose me for ever—make your election!

sp.speaker: Octav.
sp.p: This moment is presented to us by love —let us prove ourselves worthy of the boon!

sp.speaker: Seraph.
sp.p: How? by disgracing love?

sp.speaker: Octav.
sp.p: We'll argue that point hereafter; but now—

sp.speaker: Seraph.
sp.p: Hold, Sir—I am neither blind to your intention, nor to my own danger—but know you are meditating an irremediable crime!

sp.speaker: Octav.
sp.p: How irremediable? Love itself shall remedy the crimes it makes.

sp.speaker: Seraph.
sp.p: Hah! you know not what you speak of, nor can I explain myself—but let us fly!

sp.speaker: Octav.
sp.p: Then we will fly my little trembler, and Hymen shall—

sp.speaker: Seraph.
sp.p: Yet stay—I cannot go with you alone —you must consent that a lady accompanies us.

sp.speaker: Octav.
sp.p: Who?

sp.speaker: Seraph.
sp.p: No matter. You must promise me, without asking questions, to conduct her safely to Don Sebastian; and then to conduct me in safety to your father's.

sp.speaker: Octav.
sp.p: To my ghostly father you mean—to a priest?

sp.speaker: Seraph.
sp.p: No, to Don Gasper—on those terms I scale the wall with you, and on no other.

sp.speaker: Octav.
sp.p: It is odd, and mysterious; but I'll scale walls with you on any terms. Where is the lady?

sp.speaker: Seraph.
sp.p:
We shall find her in the next walk— oh, no, she is hast'ning hither. (Enter Viola, veil'd.) Come fair damsel, this is the valourous knight who is to conduct us thro' all the intervening dragons, and giants, to the quiet and sober
pale of matrimony—where we shall grow good, and stupid: (drawling) and recollect the kind action of this night, with matronly thankfulness and decency.

sp.speaker: Octav.
sp.p: (Aside.) 'Tis a vile thought, and sticks most indigestibly! Why must love be thus shackled? I feel I shall repent, and leap the pale;—but I am fairly caught now, and must submit. Come my little fawns! take each an arm.—Egad, let us make haste, or some unlucky ideas, which are growing rather ponderous, will prevent my flight over the wall!

sp.speaker: Seraph.
sp.p: I'll be hang'd if it is not the idea of matrimony you find so heavy!—but be of good comfort, Signor, and make speed—your fate has prepared a consolation you little expect. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: Well, day at last is broad awake; and the vile night, which cloaks so many schemes, and villainous plots, against the peace of wary husbands, is pass'd away—and all hath gone well! yes, all hath gone well, except with my poor aching bones, and sleepless eyes. Spent all these hours upon a mat at Antonia's chamber door—dared not leave it. Truly she is a treasure, but if to secure it I must fag out the remnant of my life in these alarms, and fears, and misgivings.—Well, well, 'tis too late now to think about that; my hour is come! (Dolefully.)

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Don Octavio, and a lady, Sir. Exit.

sp.speaker: Octav.
sp.p:
Permit me, Sir, to ask your protection
for this lady for a few hours;—if you knew her, you would think she had a right to claim it.

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: To claim it—why, who is she?

sp.speaker: Octav.
sp.p: That I am forbid to tell—do you release me from my promise, madam?

sp.speaker: Seraph.
sp.p: No, certainly;—and yet if I did, it were much the same thing, for you do not know me.

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: Not know the lady!

sp.speaker: Seraph.
sp.p: Believe me he does not; and yet if you ask him, he'll swear he does.

sp.speaker: Octav.
sp.p: Surely, tho' you are veil'd, I can swear you are the same sweet melting creature, who in a certain garden—

sp.speaker: Seraph.
sp.p: Found herself in your arms; and afterwards leapt the wall with you—that you may safely swear.

sp.speaker: Octav.
sp.p: Yet I know you not—ha, ha, ha, permit me (apart) —Perhaps you'll deny being her, whom I am to marry to day?

sp.speaker: Seraph.
sp.p: Oh, no—I swear I will marry you to day, if Don Alexis gives consent.

sp.speaker: Octav.
sp.p: We have more than his consent—his ardent wishes.

sp.speaker: Seraph.
sp.p: Yet I shall not be your's.

sp.speaker: Octav.
sp.p: Why, what a sweet enigmatical charmer you are!

sp.speaker: Seraph.
sp.p: (to Don Gasper) If I mistake not, Sir, this house has a mistress—may I be permitted to wait on Donna Antonia?

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: Madam—ma—Octavio! (Whispers.)

sp.speaker: Octav.
sp.p: Oh yes, of rank and reputation—but a little capricious.

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p:
Pardon me, madam! I will wait on you
to Antonia's apartment.—I shan't care to leave them together tho'! (Aside.)

sp.speaker: Octav.
sp.p: What can she mean with her riddle-merees? I am perplex'd (Sebastian enters with Viola.) Hah Don Sebastian! What the weighty ceremony so lightly over? Madam, I wish you all the joys which belong to your new state. Dear Sebastian (taking him aside) tell me—how dost feel?

sp.speaker: Sebas.
sp.p: Feel!

sp.speaker: Octav.
sp.p: Ay;—in a few hours I shall be in the same class, and I want to guess how it is.

sp.speaker: Sebas.
sp.p: If you love as I do, you'll feel as I do—blest!

sp.speaker: Octav.
sp.p: I fear all you married rogues are so many decoy ducks; you look up with envy, and cry quake, quake, to your fellows at large; and when you have coax'd us into the snare, clap your wings, and exult.

sp.speaker: Viola.
sp.p: (running to Sebastian.) Oh, I hear my father's voice—I would not have him see you at this instant. (Apart.) Pardon my freedom Don Octavio, but it will be infinitely kind if you'll both leave me.

sp.speaker: Sebas.
sp.p: Those fears are idle my charmer—the moment must arrive.

sp.speaker: Viola.
sp.p: Nay, do not stay to argue, but oblige me!

sp.speaker: Octav.
sp.p: What, Sir, so much of a husband in half an hour, as to dispute a command? I'll take him to task, madam, and give him a lesson on obedience. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Alexis.
sp.p: (without) Octavio, and a lady veil'd? (entering) then all is right! Hah Viola! well, tell me, is it all over—are you married?

sp.speaker: Viola.
sp.p: Yes, Sir.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Yes, Sir—enough said! ha, ha, ha,—now I can laugh at Gasper, and enjoy Don Julio's joke—ha, ha, ha—and you too—you have been finely nick'd—I have been oblig'd to cheat you into marrying the man you liked—ha, ha, ha—

sp.speaker: Viola.
sp.p: Oh, Sir, forgive what I have done!

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Forgive thee, my girl! ay that I will— here's my hand upon't.—Hah Don Gasper! (he enters) your most obedient very humble servant! How do you find yourself after your last night's whim, Sir?—My seal-ring is at your service, at any time, Don Gasper—ha, ha, ha,—two jokes at once—I shall laugh now, 'till I am a grandfather.

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: If you laugh till my Octavio makes you a grandfather, it will be a very long fit I promise ye.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Dye think so? I'll trust him!

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: He is now in the next room, at the feet of a young lady, whose charms are sufficient, I trust, to blot those of your daughter from his heart.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: What's that? Octavio at the feet of a lady! d'ye hear that, Viola?

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: Your daughter—Pardon me, fair lady!

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Ay, Sir, and your daughter too—your daughter! Let me see your encourage her husband to kneel to other women in your house.

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: Her husband—ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Zounds, Sir, this is no laughing matter —how dare you, Sir—Why, Viola, why don't you rave and storm, as women do on these occasions?

sp.speaker: Viola.
sp.p: Alas, Sir! I have no right.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: No right! I shall see that. Here Don Octavio, I say! The very day of his marriage— nay within the hour! (Enter Octavio.)

sp.speaker: Octav.
sp.p: Don Alexis—your pleasure?

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: My pleasure, Sir, is, that—Zounds!— that your pleasure shall be with my daughter.

sp.speaker: Octav.
sp.p: 'Tis very kind—nothing can make me so happy.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Then what the devil do you mean by— by—your father says you were at the feet of a lady.

sp.speaker: Octav.
sp.p: I was.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: You was!

sp.speaker: Octav.
sp.p: Why should that offend you? Do you not wish me to love your daughter?

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Love my daughter, and kneel to another!

sp.speaker: Octav.
sp.p: All mistake, Sir—another! I'll convince you that Viola alone (going to the wing) here she comes! the dear lively girl! who leapt a garden wall, to give a sober marriage the air of a romance.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Oons! where am I? are not you my daughter? (twitching off Viola's veil) yes. Did you not leap the wall with him?

sp.speaker: Viola.
sp.p: Yes, Sir.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: And are you not married?

sp.speaker: Viola.
sp.p: I am indeed! (curtseying.)

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: And did you, Madam, leap a wall?

sp.speaker: Seraph.
sp.p: Yes, Sir.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: And are you married too?

sp.speaker: Seraph.
sp.p: I am, indeed! (throws up her veil, and curtseys.)

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: My wife—Oons—my wife!

sp.speaker: Octav.
sp.p: Amazement! his wife!

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: His wife leap the wall with my Octavio —ha, ha, ha. I'll add another five hundred moidores to your yearly allowance, for that my boy! Prithee, dear Don, indulge your laugh; you were in a very fine vein a minute ago—ha, ha, ha— now laugh till you're a grandfather!

sp.speaker: Seraph.
sp.p: Don Octavio, I have used you ill; but I trust your generosity will pardon my taking advantage of your partiality for me, to serve two amiable and faithful lovers.

sp.speaker: Octav.
sp.p: You have used me ill, indeed! yet hang it, come, I am not married—I am not married however! (aside) Yes, Madam, I can forgive you; but how shall I forgive myself? I had you—oh, distraction! I had you alone—amidst the conscious shades of night—and in my power!

sp.speaker: Seraph.
sp.p: Pardon me, Sir! no woman can be alone, nor in the power of any man, whilst she respects herself, and is guarded by a sense of her duty. You see, Don Alexis, what benefits arise from plotting without a woman. Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Oh, I shall be mad! so it was my wife, then, to whom you were kneeling? and it was you whom I press'd yesterday to grant him some small favours?

sp.speaker: Seraph.
sp.p: Just so, my sweet Hubby!

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Oh!

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: Come, be merry, old Gentleman.—A companion for your seal ring—two jokes at once, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Ay, you have it all to nothing now. And you have the impudence to love my wife? (to Octavio.)

sp.speaker: Octav.
sp.p: More than ever, now there's no danger of matrimony.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: And you are now considering when you shall make me a — a satyr, eh? come, be frank— when is it to be?

sp.speaker: Octav.
sp.p: Faith, I wish I could tell.

sp.speaker: Seraph.
sp.p: I will answer for him!—it shall be never; whilst you repose a generous confidence in me, and allow me to be the guardian of my own honour. (Don Gasp. goes out.)

sp.speaker: Octav.
sp.p: Now I intreat you, my dear Don Alexis, be a very tyrant! suspect her, watch her, and confine her—will you be so much my friend?

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: I don't know what I shall be yet;—both as husband and father, I have ingeniously contrived to bite myself most d—n—bly! As for you, Madam, (to Viola) bread and water, and a dark chamber, shall be your lot—

sp.speaker: Sebas.
sp.p: (entering) No, Sir,—I am the arbiter of her lot;—however, I confirm half your punishment; and a dark chamber she shall certainly have This is the expression, I am told, which had nearly prov'd fatal to the Comedy. I should not have printed it, but from the resolution I have religiously kept, of restoring every thing that was objected to..

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: What then, thou art really married—and married to Sebastian!

sp.speaker: Viola.
sp.p: Dear, Sir, you assured me, that of the two fools you preferred him.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Yes, but I depended on your perverseness, hussey?

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: (Leading in Antonia) Come, you, who have not seen my little pet, behold her—Nay, I present her to ye all, as the pattern of meekness and perfect love—Oh its a sweet pudsey.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Meekness, alas! you should not answer for; you know I am a woman. My perfect love, indeed you may—the world has not a heart so truly wedded as Antonia's—behold its master— its lawful lord, my husband! (Pointing to the opposite door.)

sp.speaker: Don Henry.
sp.p: (entering) Come, my Antonia, to his arms! Yes, I am thy husband —now I stand boldly forward, and proclaim my title—I am thy husband! that dear distinction which heaven has blest me with, heaven only shall reclaim!

sp.speaker: Octav.
sp.p: What! am I to lose my mother as well as my wife?

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: (To Gasp.) Your nephew! why is this full moon? We are all going to run out of our wits.

sp.speaker: Seraph.
sp.p: Don't be dishearten'd—tho' it should be so—You'll not have far to run!

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: Why Julio, what in the name of—

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: No, Sir—not Julio, but Don Henry. That Don Henry whom you so basely reported to be dead; that you might dishonour him in security.

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: How!—why—why you are dead—as good as dead; you are dead in law—you are outlaw'd, banish'd—

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: No, Sir, neither—restored to my country! Behold my pardon! (Shews a paper.)

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: Your pardon!—hum! Now, then I see the whole;—I must be telling my secrets, with a devil to it! Well you got it through me you know—you may thank the music of my moidores for that dance!

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: No, Sir! (throwing down a purse) there is the gold you basely barter'd for the pardon you solicited. My pardon I obtain'd from the hands of majesty itself—from our gracious queen! Oh, when her kingdom's foes provoke correction from her subjects arms, then shall my sword again be drawn, nor ask forgiveness for its ardent duty!

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: Well, very well—but what has your pardon to do with my wife? (putting her behind him) What have you to do with Tony?

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: She is my wife; made mine by contract, before you destin'd her the bliss of being your's. Pardon me then, my sweet Antonia! (taking her from Gasper) if I deprive you of his venerable charmer, and give you in his place a husband!

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Hum! hum! (Sings.)
sp.l: Once I was a merry old man,
But now the case is chang'd!
sp.p: Who could have thought that my old seal ring would ever have been a talisman to make lovers happy, and save a Greybeard from folly?

sp.speaker: Seraph.
sp.p: Come Don Gasper, let me advise you to think your loss a gain—you see in your humble servant, what mischievous creatures young wives are;—she'd plague your heart out, as I do my old husband's.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Faith she says true. A minute ago I thought the laugh on my side; but 'tis still on your own. You have lost a young wife, and I have found one.

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: Why, to say truth, if it were not that at present I feel a little aukward, and don't know very well which way to look.—As to your contract I might perhaps dispute its powers, but as here is a stroke or two of mine, which may be, I shan't be sorry to have drop'd, e'en go to church i'gad's name; and when ye come home beware of plots and scal rings!

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: This is generous! The sentiments you profess'd for me I see will be converted to a more decent regard, and we shall all be united in the bands of charming friendship.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Gad this looks like a sort of general amnesty—so let the frolick go round! But dare my faults hope forgiveness here? (to the house) Yes;—I am on this spot an old offender; and have so often gratefully experienced the candour of my judges, that I trust now to meet their pardon — and invoke the gracious sign!

div1.head: EPILOGUE,
div1.l: A Mourning Bride!—that wou'd be something new—
(That I'm a Mourning Husband is too true,
Cries old Sir Testy in his gouty chair,)
"Ah could I wedlock's fatal slip repair!
"But young wives are a sort of flying gout,
"Torments for which no cure was e'er found out;
"Both old men's plagues, to punish youthful tricks,
"Equally difficult, I fear, to fix.
"Of wife and gout alike I stand in dread,
"For both, alas! sometimes affect the head."
Thus rail old cynics, striving to disparage
The charming silken ties of modern marriage.
In former times, when folks agreed to wed,
The silent bride by silent bridegroom led,
Up to the altar march'd in solemn state,
All was demure, and stupidly sedate.
Impress'd with awe, while neither dar'd to speak,
A wedding was a mere Ballet Tragique.
Thank Heav'n we're past the ages of romance;
Wedlock is now a kind of country dance,
Where man and wife with smiles each other greet,
Take hands, change sides, and part as soon as meet;
Pleasure's soft accents ev'ry care dispel,
While Hymen fiddles Vive la Bagatelle.
Blest age! when ceremony's chains are worn,
Like bracelets, not to setter, but adorn.
When we assume deep mourning's fable shew,
'Tis etiquette prescribes the form of woe:
Whate'er our loss, we must have fashion's leave,
Ere we can venture decently to grieve.
Blameless the heir o'er the dear parchment chuckles,
If he's unpowder'd, and puts on black buckles,
Till the grey frock speaks his first anguish o'er,
And he's but half as wretched as before.
Ere the gay widow first abroad is seen,
Deck'd in exhilarating bombazeen,
While the dear Col'nel visits unsuspected,
And she's as well as could have been expected;
Custom's indulgence wisely does she borrow,
In cards of compliments exhausts her sorrow;
Of tears her black-edg'd paper fills the place,
Mourns as her proxy, and preserves her face.
Our Mourning Bride, who with no sorrow labours,
And mourns but in appearance, like her neighbours,
Tho' forc'd by etiquette, good humour loves, as well as any here,
Blest in the fate which these kind smiles decree her,
She hopes her friends will often come to see her.
